questions.text: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired leukocyte adhesion is seen in leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, which may present with recurrent infections during childhood. However, affected children would have a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump, omphalitis, and/or impaired wound healing instead of recurrent streptococcal infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective formation of the membrane attack complex occurs in terminal complement deficiency, which puts affected individuals at increased risk for Neisseria infections (e.g., Meningococcal meningitis). There is no increased susceptibility to streptococcal infections as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective superoxide production by neutrophils and macrophages is seen in chronic granulomatous disease due to a defect in NADPH oxidase. While this condition is also characterized by recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus) is more common, rather than the catalase-negative (e.g., Streptococcus) infections seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Complement factor C3 is a precursor for C3b, which plays a major role in opsonization of pathogens and immune complexes. C3 deficiency results in increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Patients with C3 deficiency classically present with recurring severe upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis), pneumonia, and meningitis, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with selective IgA deficiency are usually asymptomatic but may present with recurrent airway infections (IgA plays an important role in mucosal immunity) and anaphylactic reactions. Although this patient has recurrent upper respiratory infections and current hypersensitivity reaction, her history of recurrent streptococcal meningitis suggests impaired complement-mediated immunity. Moreover, other manifestations of selective IgA deficiency such as atopy and a history of GI infections are missing in this patient.
questions.hint: This girl's history of recurrent streptococcal infections and current hypersensitivity reaction is concerning for C3 deficiency.

questions.text: Five days after receiving chemotherapy for ovarian cancer, a 74-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She feels well and has no complaints. Her leukocyte count is 3,500/mm3 (11% neutrophils and 89% lymphocytes). This patient's profound granulocytopenia is most likely to predispose her to infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with severe neutropenia (including this patient with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia) are at increased risk of developing pyogenic and/or enteric bacterial infections. Enterococcus faecalis is an enteric gram-positive organism that is part of the normal GI flora and can cause serious nosocomial urinary tract and biliary tract infections, bacteremia, and infective endocarditis in neutropenic patients. Prolonged neutropenia (> 7 days) can also predispose to fungal infections (especially Candida and Aspergillus species).

B) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable commensal bacteria found in the genitourinary tract. Alterations in vaginal pH (e.g., via douching) or changes in the composition of the normal vaginal flora (e.g., due to antibiotics) can predispose patients to vulvovaginitis caused by this bacteria. Neutropenia is not a known risk factor for the development of Gardnerella vaginitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Giardia lamblia is a protozoa that can cause diarrhea in both healthy and immunocompromised patients. Patients with IgA deficiency are at especially increased risk of developing giardiasis, due to impaired gut immunity. This patient has a normal lymphocyte count and her neutropenia is unlikely to predispose her to infection with Giardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus infection is usually asymptomatic in healthy individuals but may cause more serious infection (e.g., pneumonia, esophagitis) in patients with T-cell or natural killer cell dysfunction. It is uncommon in patients with neutropenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients with T-cell dysfunction (e.g., due to HIV/AIDS). This patient has a normal lymphocyte count, making an infection with Pneumocystis jirovecii unlikely.
questions.hint: Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) is the product of leukocyte count and percent neutrophils. A leukocyte count of 3,500/mm3 with 11% neutrophils corresponds to an ANC of 385 cells/μL. An ANC below 500 cells/μL is classified as severe neutropenia.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe muscle pain and fever for 4 days. He likes to go hunting and consumed bear meat 1 month ago. Examination shows periorbital edema and generalized muscle tenderness. His leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 with 19% eosinophils. The release of major basic protein in response to this patient’s infection is most likely a result of which of the following?

choices.text: Interaction between Th1 cells and macrophages
Increased expression of MHC class I molecules
Increased expression of MHC class II molecules

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune complex-dependent complement activation is the underlying mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions. However, this patient has a helminthic infection, which generates an immune response with a different molecular mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

The interaction between Th1 cells and macrophages augments antigen presentation and the immune response to intracellular pathogens, and interferon-γ and TNF-α are key molecules in this pathway. This mechanism is most active in defense against intracellular bacteria and viruses, not helminthic infections such as the trichinellosis seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased expression of MHC class I molecules occurs in response to interferon-α and interferon-β secretion. Host cells infected with viruses secrete interferon-α to augment the immune response to the pathogen, while fibroblasts are the major producers of interferon-β. However, MHC class I molecules do not play a role in the defense against helminthic infections such as the trichinellosis seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased expression of MHC class II molecules occurs in response to interferon-γ, which is produced by activated Th1 cells and natural killer cells and plays a major role in granuloma formation. This mechanism is not involved in the defense against helminthic infections such as the trichinellosis seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity is critical for defense against helminthic infections. IgE molecules coat pathogens and are subsequently recognized by Fc receptor-bearing granulocytes, including eosinophils. The interaction of the IgE molecule and the receptor stimulates the release of cytotoxic granules such as major basic protein, which ultimately leads to the destruction of the pathogen.
questions.hint: This man has periorbital edema, symptoms of myositis, fever, and eosinophilia after consuming bear meat. This suggests the diagnosis of trichinellosis. Major basic protein plays an important role in defending against helminthic infections.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for progressively worsening episodes of severe crampy abdominal pain and nonbloody diarrhea for the past 3 years. Examination of the abdomen shows mild distension and generalized tenderness. There is a fistula draining stool in the perianal region. Immunohistochemistry shows dysfunction of the cytosolic nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) receptor. In-vitro studies show that this receptor is usually involved in activation of the innate immune system in response to certain pathogen-associated patterns (PAMPs). Which of the following proteins is most likely to be produced upon activation of this receptor?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

β-Catenin activity is regulated by the Wnt signaling mechanism. Increased β-catenin activity causes cellular proliferation, and inappropriately active β-catenin can lead to neoplastic growth. However, NOD2 protein is not involved in the regulation of β-catenin.

B) INCORRECT:

IgM is the first antibodies produced by plasma cells in the spleen and lymph nodes in response to initial contact with a new antigen. Immunoglobulins have a crucial role in the adaptive immune system, not the innate immune system.

C) CORRECT:

Activation of NOD-like receptors, a type of pattern recognition receptor (PRR), leads to the upregulation of NF-κB, which plays an important role in the innate immune system by increasing transcription of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-1β, IL-18). By recognizing PAMPs (e.g., LPS, flagellin, peptidoglycan) on non-self molecules, PRRs activate the innate immune system and provide an immediate response to pathogens. However, mutations in the NOD2 receptor, as seen in this patient with Crohn disease, alter NF-κB activity, leading to a dysfunctional innate immune response.

Defects in NOD2 receptor activity have also been linked to sarcoidosis and graft-versus-host disease.

D) INCORRECT:

IL-10 is a potent anti-inflammatory cytokine. The immunological hallmark of Crohn disease is inappropriately active autoinflammatory mechanisms, so IL-10 activity would be expected to be normal or low but not increased. In fact, IL-10 supplementation is being considered as a therapy for Crohn disease. Moreover, NOD2 receptors mutations have been shown to suppress IL-10 secretion.

E) INCORRECT:

TGF-β is a potent anti-inflammatory cytokine produced by numerous members of the immune system (e.g., macrophages, regulatory T cells). Its anti-inflammatory properties include inhibition of B lymphocytes and macrophages, as well as activation of regulatory T cells and Th17 cells. NOD2 receptors, however, activate the immune system by increasing pro-inflammatory cytokine production, whereas TGF-β is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that helps to de-escalate the immune response and encourage healing. Moreover, TGF-β secretion is not directly affected by NOD2 receptors, so secretion would not be altered by a NOD2 receptor mutation.
questions.hint: Like toll-like receptors (TLRs), NOD receptors recognize non-self molecular markers (e.g., bacterial proteins) and upon activation induce the production of proinflammatory cytokines.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever, chills, nausea, and abdominal pain. He does not use illicit drugs. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 6-cm solitary, fluid-filled cavity in the right hepatic lobe. CT-guided percutaneous aspiration of the cavity produces yellowish-green fluid. Culture of the aspirated fluid grows gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the color of the aspirated fluid?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyoverdine is a yellowish-green pigment produced and secreted by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Unlike the organism isolated here, Pseudomonas spp. are non-lactose fermenters and seldom cause liver abscesses.

B) INCORRECT:

Polysaccharide capsules form the outermost layer of encapsulated organisms but are not responsible for the yellowish-green color of pus. In certain bacterial infections, such as Klebsiella pneumonia, the polysaccharide capsule may account for the reddish color of currant-jelly sputum. Furthermore, the presence of encapsulated bacteria may cause secretions to become mucoid in nature, which is not observed in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Prodigiosin is a red pigment produced by Serratia marcescens. Like E. coli and Klebsiella, S. marcescens is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rod and is not a common cause of liver abscesses. Furthermore, the pigment produced by S. marcescens would not cause pus to assume a yellowish-green color.
Image Description:

Agar gel plate

Several isolated, partially confluent, round colonies of Serratia marcescens can be seen on the agar medium. The colonies appear red due to the production of a color pigment (prodigiosin).

D) CORRECT:

Myeloperoxidase (MPO), a lysosomal enzyme produced by neutrophils, is responsible for the yellowish-green color of the pus. Neutrophils store MPO in granules and then release it into the extracellular space where MPO has an antimicrobial effect. MPO has a heme moiety that would cause the color of the pus observed here. A similar color can be seen in Pseudomonas infections in which the greenish pigment pyoverdine is produced by the bacteria. However, pyogenic liver abscesses are rarely caused by Pseudomonas, and MPO is the most likely cause of the yellowish-green coloration.
Image Description:

I: Activation of NADPH oxidase produces superoxide radicals, a process known as a respiratory or oxidative burst
II: Superoxide dismutase catalyzes superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
III: Myeloperoxidase, released by azurophilic granules, converts H2O2 to hypochlorous acid (HClO), a potent antimicrobial agent.
IV–VI: Superoxides are detoxified through a series of redox reactions, replenishing the NADPH consumed during the respiratory burst.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphyloxanthin is responsible for the golden yellow color of pus in infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus, which are gram-positive cocci. While S. aureus is a common cause of pyogenic liver abscesses in children, it is seldom a cause of liver infections in adults.

F) INCORRECT:

β-galactosidase is an enzyme produced by lactose-fermenting organisms such as E. coli. While this enzyme does cause colonies of lactose-fermenting bacteria to turn pink on MacConkey agar, it has no in vivo effect. It would therefore not account for the color of this patient's pus.

G) INCORRECT:

Sulfur granules cause the characteristic yellow discharge seen in actinomycosis. Actinomycosis is caused by the gram-positive bacillus Actinomyces israelii and usually manifests with orofacial, pelvic, or soft tissue infections rather than hepatic abscesses. Moreover, the presence of gram-negative rods on culture rules out actinomycosis in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Biliverdin is a green pigment formed by the breakdown of hemoglobin. It would not be present in pus, but the greenish color of bruises following soft tissue trauma is caused by biliverdin, which accumulates after the breakdown of extravasated hemoglobin.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a pyogenic liver abscess. In adults, E. coli is the most common cause of pyogenic liver abscesses, followed by Klebsiella. Both organisms are gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods. The yellowish-green fluid is pus, which is predominantly composed of neutrophils.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, chills, headache, and fatigue. He appears ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Analysis of nasal secretions shows infection with an enveloped, single-stranded segmented RNA virus. In response to infection with this pathogen, certain cells present antigens from the pathogen to CD8+ T-lymphocytes. Which of the following statements about the molecules used for the presentation of these antigens is most accurate?

choices.text: The antigens are loaded onto the molecule within lysosomes
The molecule consists of a heavy chain associated with β2 microglobulin
The molecule is made up of 2 chains of equal length
The molecule is used for the presentation of exogenously synthesized antigens
The molecule induces activation of a humoral immune response
The molecule is selectively expressed by antigen-presenting cells
The molecule is a product of the HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and -DR genes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antigens are loaded onto MHC II receptors in lysosomes. However, MHC II does not activate CD8+ T-lymphocytes. CD8+ T-lymphocytes are activated by antigens presented on MHC I, These antigens are loaded onto MHC I in the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

B) CORRECT:

Nucleated cells can present viral antigens to CD8+ T-lymphocytes using MHC I, which consists of an alpha chain and β2 microglobulin. The alpha chain of the MHC I is produced from HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C genes and contains a groove that binds intracellular antigens. Antigens are presented when the proteasome breaks down viral protein expressed inside nucleated cells into peptides, which are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum cells via the TAP transporter protein and loaded onto MHC I. The antigen-MHC I complex is transported to the cell membrane for antigen presentation to CD8+ T-lymphocytes.
Image Description:

MHC class I proteins consist of a heavy α chain and the stabilizing β2 microglobulin, which are held together by a noncovalent bond. The α chain is composed of three individual domains (α1–α3) and forms the antigen-binding groove (peptide-binding site).

MHC class II proteins consist of one α and one β chain, each of which is in turn composed of two domains (α1 and α2; β1 and β2). Each chain is independently anchored to the cell membrane via a transmembrane segment. Together, both chains form the peptide-binding site.

C) INCORRECT:

MHC II is composed of two long chains of equal length. However, MHC II activates CD4+ cells, not CD8+ T-lymphocytes. MHC I is composed of a long chain and a short chain.

D) INCORRECT:

Exogenous antigens are presented on MHC II, which activates CD4+ T-lymphocytes and B-lymphocytes. However, MHC II does not activate CD8+ T-lymphocytes. The MHC I molecule, which activates CD8+ T-lymphocytes, presents endogenous antigens (e.g., cytosolic antigens of the organisms, antigens of intracellular pathogens such as viruses).

E) INCORRECT:

Antigen presentation to CD8+ T lymphocytes, as seen in this patient, can induce cell-mediated immunity. Humoral immunity results from antibodies expressed and secreted by B-lymphocytes, which are activated by CD4+ T-lymphocytes using MHC II and not by CD8+ T-lymphocytes or MHC I.

F) INCORRECT:

Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) selectively express MHC II, which activate CD4+ T-lymphocytes and B-lymphocytes. MHC II does not activate CD8+ T-lymphocytes. The MHC I molecule, which activates CD8+ T-lymphocytes, is expressed not only by APCs but by all nucleated cells.

G) INCORRECT:

MHC II, which activates CD4+ T-lymphocytes and B-lymphocytes, is a product of HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR genes. However, MHC II does not activate CD8+ T-lymphocytes. MHC I, which is involved in antigen presentation to CD8+ T-lymphocytes, is produced from HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C genes.
questions.hint: This patient has influenza, which is caused by infection with an enveloped, negative-sense, single-stranded segmented RNA virus. The immune response mediated by CD8+ T-cells is required to kill intracellular pathogens such as viruses. Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages present the antigens derived from the virus on MHC I to the T cell receptors of CD8+ cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with multiple myeloma is admitted to the hospital for induction chemotherapy prior to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The results of a bone marrow biopsy had shown a t(14;16) translocation. Therapy with lenalidomide, low-dose dexamethasone, and carfilzomib is initiated. Carfilzomib therapy most likely has which of the following effects?

choices.text: Increased complement-mediated cytolysis of B lymphocytes
Increased transition from the G2 phase to the M phase of the cell cycle
Decreased activation of CD8+ T cells
Decreased antigen presentation on MHC II molecules

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased complement-mediated cytolysis of B lymphocytes is induced by rituximab, a monoclonal antibody that binds to CD20. Carfilzomib is a proteasome inhibitor that is not known to affect B lymphocyte function or survival.
Image Description:

- Complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC): The recruitment of proteins of the complement system (e.g., C1) results in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), disrupting the cell membrane and causing B-cell lysis.

- Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC): Effector immune cells (e.g, natural killer cells, macrophages) bind to the Fc tail of rituximab with their Fc receptors and kill the B cells.

- Direct apoptosis: The binding of rituximab to the CD20 receptor can also lead to direct induction of apoptosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Carfilzomib decreases protein degradation by proteasomes and exerts an antitumor effect by disrupting protein homeostasis, which results in cell cycle arrest, from the G2 phase to the M phase of the cell cycle, not increased transition.

C) CORRECT:

Carfilzomib decreases protein degradation by proteasomes and exerts an antitumor effect by protein homeostasis disruption, which results in cell cycle arrest at the G2 checkpoint. Proteasomes normally process endogenous antigens (e.g., viral and cytosolic proteins). Carfilzomib therapy, therefore, decreases the availability of endogenous antigen fragments. These antigen fragments are normally delivered by the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) to the rough endoplasmic reticulum, where they are then loaded onto MHC I molecules, which are responsible for presenting antigens to activate CD8+ T cells. Carfilzomib therapy, therefore, decreases the activation of CD8+ T cells.

Carfilzomib therapy is associated with an increased risk of herpes zoster reactivation as a result of decreased activity of CD8+ T cells.
Image Description:

MHC class I antigen presentation: Intracellular proteins are degraded to small peptide fragments by the proteasome and released into the cytosol. The cytosolic peptides enter the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) via the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) to form a complex with MHC class I molecule. The newly formed MHC class I antigen complex undergoes post-translational modification within the Golgi apparatus and enters the cell surface for presentation to cytotoxic CD8 T-cells.

MHC class II antigen presentation: Extracellular proteins are ingested by the antigen-presenting cell and held within the endosome. The protein is degraded into small peptides by the lysosome, which then forms a complex with the MHC class II protein. The new MHC class II antigen complex is transported to the cell surface for presentation with CD4 T-cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased polymerization of β-tubulin is induced by vinca alkaloids, which bind to β-tubulin and inhibit microtubule formation and mitotic spindle formation, arresting the cell cycle in metaphase. Carfilzomib is a proteasome inhibitor that is not known to affect β-tubulin polymerization.

E) INCORRECT:

Antigen processing for MHC II molecules occurs in lysosomes and is not affected by the activity of carfilzomib, which inhibits proteasome function. Lysosomes normally process exogenous antigens (e.g., bacterial proteins) after they are ingested and held in endosomes. These antigen fragments are loaded onto MHC II molecules, which are responsible for presenting antigens to activate CD4+ helper T cells.
questions.hint: Carfilzomib is a proteasome inhibitor. Proteasomes degrade proteins and are responsible for processing antigens into peptide fragments that are delivered to MHC I molecules.
